docs.lead_paragraph: Hockey Canada has stepped forward to fill the void after the N.H.L.'s assertion last month that its insurance coverage did not extend to those players who attend pre-Olympic orientation camps this summer.

headline.main: Hockey Canada Steps Up in N.H.L.'s Absence on Insurance Coverage

docs.abstract: Hockey Canada extends full insurance coverage for players participating at its pre-Olympic orientation camp in Calgary next week.
docs.snippet: Hockey Canada extends full insurance coverage for players participating at its pre-Olympic orientation camp in Calgary next week.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no question older Americans are worried that any health care overhaul may cut end up cutting their benefits, even if the worst of those fears are being stoked by misinformation.
docs.abstract: How is it so many seem unaware that Medicare is run by the federal government? There are several reasons, experts say.
docs.snippet: How is it so many seem unaware that Medicare is run by the federal government? There are several reasons, experts say.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, suggested on Friday that a public insurance option might have to be discarded to ensure health care legislation is approved, barely a day after Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said the House would not pass a package that did not include a public plan. Read more on the Prescriptions Blog.

headline.main: House Democrats Tussle Over Public Plan

docs.abstract: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer offers the latest comments in what has recently turned into a sort of tug of war between Democrats over the necessity of a public option.
docs.snippet: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer offers the latest comments in what has recently turned into a sort of tug of war between Democrats over the necessity of a public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, suggested on Friday that a public insurance option might have to be discarded to ensure health care legislation is approved, a day after Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said the House would not pass a package that did not include a public plan.

headline.main: House Democrats Tussle Over Public Plan

docs.abstract: The speaker says the public plan must be included. Maybe not, says the majority leader.
docs.snippet: The speaker says the public plan must be included. Maybe not, says the majority leader.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the third installment of answers to reader questions about continuing education, in a follow-up to yesterday's special coverage of the subject. Find the previous Q.&A. posts here and here.

headline.main: Answering Your Questions on Continuing Education, III

docs.abstract: More answers to readers' questions about financing their continuing educations and determining which program will put them on track to an in-demand career.
docs.snippet: More answers to readers' questions about financing their continuing educations and determining which program will put them on track to an in-demand career.

byline.original: By TARA SIEGEL BERNARD and CATHERINE RAMPELL

docs.lead_paragraph: Our neighbors over at the You're the Boss blog are inviting small-business readers to share their experiences with the type of health insurance that includes health savings accounts. It's pegged to the food fight that the Whole Foods Markets chief John Mackey prompted recently with a Wall Street Journal op-ed article, criticizing the Obama administration's approach to health care reform.
docs.abstract: The You're the Boss blog is soliciting comments about health savings accounts.
docs.snippet: The You're the Boss blog is soliciting comments about health savings accounts.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Mackey, the co-founder and chief executive of Whole Foods Markets, recently started something of a food fight with a column in The Wall Street Journal that criticized the Obama administration's approach to health care reform and offered Mr. Mackey's own suggested reforms. Somewhat lost in the ensuing tussle was the notion that offering employees a combination of a high-deductible health insurance plan along with health savings accounts had worked for Whole Foods and could form the basis for a national solution to health care.

headline.main: Are High Deductibles and Health Savings Accounts the Answer?

docs.abstract: Is the combination a winning strategy for small businesses? Does it offer lessons that should inform our debate about health-care reform?
docs.snippet: Is the combination a winning strategy for small businesses? Does it offer lessons that should inform our debate about health-care reform?

docs.lead_paragraph: As the summer recess drives the health care debate out of Washington and the administration's control, President Obama turns to former Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle for some guidance this morning.
docs.abstract: The president and former Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle sit down for a White House chat.
docs.snippet: The president and former Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle sit down for a White House chat.

docs.lead_paragraph: Our cousins at the Economix blog this morning have posted a column by the Princeton economist Uwe E. Reinhardt. He argues that the real reason so many people like the idea of a government-run public insurance plan is because it might give them far more certainty about their medical coverage than the current system - which relies chiefly on private insurance obtained through employers.

headline.main: When Insurance Is Far From Assured

docs.abstract: An economist argues that certainty, not a desire for competition, is the reason many Americans favor a public insurance plan.
docs.snippet: An economist argues that certainty, not a desire for competition, is the reason many Americans favor a public insurance plan.

docs.abstract: There are ways to develop universal health care coverage that don't include a public option. Let's hear what they'd look like, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: There are ways to develop universal health care coverage that don't include a public option. Let's hear what they'd look like, an economist writes.
